div1.p: Deposition

of James D. Doty, of Taycheedah in the Territory of Wiskonsan, to be read in evidence in the case of Amelia Thompson &c of Color, Complainants and William (R.) Jouett, defendent, in the Louisville Chancery Court, in the State of Kentucky, taken by Charles Doty under and by virtue of a Commission issued to him by the said Court, bearing date the 2nd day of November 1844 amd hereunto annexed.
I, the Said James D. Doty being duly sworn do testify, depose and say, in reply to the several interrogatories annexed to the said Commission as follows, to wit:
To the 1st Intertogatory
That I am acquainted with the parties to this Suit
To the 2nd. Interrogatory
That I have no knowledge of their purchase by the defendent
To the 3d. Interrogatory
That I have known the Said Jouett as an officer in the Army of

the United States for thirteen years (and more) last part: That I have frequently seen him on Service as such officer, at the United States Garrisons at Fort Crawford and at Fort Winnebago in the Territory of Wiskonsan
To the 4th. Interrogatory

That since the latter part of the year 1841 or the beginning of the year 1842 (or thereabouts) the said Jouett has been stationed at said Fort.Winnebago, in command of that post: That his quarters are and at all times been within the pickets of the Garrison: That the said Fort is on land which is reserved by the United States for Military purposes, over which the Territorial authorities exercise no civil jurisdiction otherwise than in the execution of the laws of the United States: That I have frequently visited the said Jouett at his quarters in the in the said Garrison, on some of which occasions I have seen (as I suppose) the said Complainanrs, who were engaged in domestic service in the quarters of the said Jouett. That they were regarded in the family of the said Jouett, and spoken of by him and them, as his slaves: That I understood he had brought them with him from Kentucky when he came to this Post.
To the 5th. Interrogatory
That the reply is contained (so far as I know) in my answer
To the 6th Interrogatory

That during the time the deft. held the Complainants in his service as his slaves in this Territory, he resided and kept them (as before stated) within the said Garrison of Fort Winnebago, on the Military Reservation of the United States; and that the said Jouett has continued to occupy quarters in the said garrison from that time to the present.
To the 7th. Interrogatory

That the defendant has not to my knowledge been in the said Territory, during the period I have known him, for any other purpose than to obey the orders of his superior officers as he had during the whole of that time been a member of the army: That such officer as

aforesaid, acting under the orders of his superior, he had not, in my opinion, the choice of a place of residence either here or elsewhere; it being contrary to Military usage, as I understand, for an officeer to select his station--- of course it cannot be optional with him how long he shall remain at any post; he comes to a Post, and remains there, at the wish of his government. If he refuse to obey he may be punished for his disobedience-- and the committing this offence can give him no civil rights when it occurs; he may seek to avoid an order to move to or from a Post by tendering a resignation of his commission; but the President may refuse to accept his resignation; and if the officer attempts to exercise his own will he becomes liable to be tried for his disobedience. The defendant therefore could not have come to this Territory "to reside," he came in the Military service, and for the purpose expressed in his orders: he came for the purpose of the government and not for his own, and could have legally had no other intention than to comply with and to execute them. To acquire residence in a country I understand that it is necessary that the person should have liberty to remain or go to another--- that he should have the will to choose --- and that he should actually determine for himself whether his domicil shall be at the place where he is or continue at the place where he previously dwelt. These remarks I have deemed necessary that my reply to this and to the 10th interrogatories may be correctly understood --- which is that Jouett did not come "to reside permanently in Wiskonsan"

And I will add farther, in reply, that Jouett has, during the time he held the complainants in his service in this Territory, dwelt upon a Military Reservation which is under the sole and exclusive jurisdiction of the United States; and that no man can obtain a "permanent" residence on such a reservation as every person there is under a Military juris- diction and subject to be removed at any moment. The Acts of Congress, also, prohibit all settlement upon lands so situated, and indeed upon all public lands except such as are subject to pre-emption. No residence therefore, either permanent or otherwise can be acquired on such lands.
To the 8th. Interrogatory I answer that I do not know.
To the 9th. Interrogatory
That I believe the defendants home and citizenship are in Kentucky, and that they were there when he entered the Army; and that his rank is now that of a Captain.
To the 10th. Interrogatory

That the deft. Jouett was not a citizen of Wiskonsan when he entered the army, and that he is not now a citizen of this Territory. Residence, with the intention to become a citizen, having the liberty to form such intention, I consider requisite to obtain citizenship. An officer of the army can have no such residence and intention: and I regard him as being in the same condition as an officer of the navy on the high seas, or in the ports of the United States, or those of foreign countries. His residence in this or any other country can only be temporary whilst he is in the service. To-day he may be ordered to a Post within this Territory, and before reaching it, or before he has been here six months, he may be ordered to another beyond its limits.

The law in this Territory is well settled, that no officer or Soldier has the right to vote at elections, for the reason that he is not regarded as a citizen or inhabitant, or required to perform any civil duty. This I consider the only test of citizenship in this territory. This opinion was confirmed by the Report of the Committee on Elections in the House of Representatives of the Congress of the United States in the year 1826, in the case of Wing, Bidal and Richard, which was accepted by the House. The following is a true extract from that Report as published by the Printer for that House, to wit:

"The second class [of voters] to which objections are made, consists "of soldiers of the army, discharged from service within one year next "preceeding the election. the committee must consider it entirely unnecessary "to enter into an argument to prove that officers and soldiers of the "army, by being long quarterred in the Territory, do not by that means "acquire the right to vote at an election, whilst they remain in the service; nor do they consider it any more necessary to attmept to prove "that, after being discharged, they must acquire the rights of the elctors.
"in the same way that other persons would who had not been in the "service."
The act of Congress entitled "An act establishing the Territorial Government of Wiskonsan," approved April 25, 1836, provides in the 5th Section as follows, to wit:"

"That every free, white male citizen of the United States, above the "age of 21 years, who shall have been an inhabitant of said Territory at "the time of its organization, shall be eligible to any office within the said Territory; "but the qualifications of voters shall be determined by the legislive Asssembly&c."

At "the first election" held for members of the Assembly under the above act, officers and soldiers who were stationed at said Fort Winnebago "at the time of the organization" of the Territory, voted. Their right was contested and their votes rejected by the House of Representatives of said Territory as will appear by the Journal of said House, of the First Legislative Assembly of Wiskonsan. The said election was held at the Sutlers Store on the said Military Reservation, under the authority of a proclamation issued by Governor Dodge. The legality of said election was also contested for this reason, and the objection sustained.

On the 4th. of July 1839. an act was passed by the Legislature of said Territory, entitled "An act to provide for and regulate general elections; the 12th. section of which provides as follows, to wit:

"No person shall be entitled to vote at any election in this "Territory who has not attained the age of 21 years, who is not a free, "white, male citizen, or a foreigner duly naturalized according to the "acts of Congress on that subject, and who has not resided in this "Territory with the bona fide intention of becoming a citizen, for art least "six months &c."

The opinion that officers and soldiers of the army are not regarded as citizens of the Territory, but merely as transient persons, having a temporary residence only, is sustained by the act of the Legis- lature of said Territory, entitled, "An Act to provide for the taking the "census of the inhabitants of the Territory of Wiskonsan, and to authorise ":the Governor to apportion the members of the Council and House of "Representatives," approved February 18. 1842. The 1sr sec. of this act provides --- "That the sheriffs of the several Counties of the Territory "are hereby authorised and required to cause the number of inhabitants "of their respective Counties and districts to be taken, omitting in "their enumeration Indians not Citizens and pffocers and soldiers of "the United States army." And the 10th. sec. provides, that "In making "said apportionment the Governor shall proceed in the manner following, to wit:

1st. The whole number of representative population of the Territory, "excluding soldiers and officerts of the United States Army, and Indians "not citizens, shall be divided by the number 52, the whole number of "units of representation, the quotient shall be the ratio, or the number "of population entitled to a unit of representation." At the time of the passage of said act I was Governor of the Said Territory and approved it; and did also make the apportionment in the manner required thereby. The officers and soldiers therefore stationed within the Territory--- although several of them had been here several years were not considered citizens or as any part of the population of the Territory.
To the 11th. Interrogatory I answer

That there is no other law in the force in this Territory prohi- biting slavery than the provision in the 6th. Article of the Ordinance of 1787, which is entitled "An Ordinance for the government of the "Territory of the U. S. northwest of the River Ohio." The Legislature of this Territory (W) has passed no law on the subject of slavery, nor made any provision to carry this article into effect.

That my opinion being asked in this Interrogatory upon the law of this Country as applicable to the facts of this case, I reply that having seen the Compts. bill & defts. answer (or copies of them) and from the facts known to me and hereinbefore stated, I am of the opinion that the complainants did not become ffree (if they were slaves in Kentucky) in consequence of their being held to service by him at Fort Winnebago. The defendant, being an officer in the U. S. army, ordered to a post within the Territory for the sole purpose of performing a military duty, and liable to be removed at any moment to any other station, can only be regarded as a transient person, incable of acquiring a domicil here, and is as much entitled to the possession of his slaves whilst tarrying here as he is to the possession of any other property. I consider that he is entitled to hold while he is in the performance of his duties any and every species of property which he has lawfully acquired and held in any of the United States, and that he is protected therein by the constitution and laws of the United States.

The defendant is required to be here by the United States, and it cannot be supposed that the U. S. would permit him to hold a slave in Florida, or in any other place under their executive jurisdiction, and not allow him the same privilege at the Military Stations in this Territory; or that it would compel him to give his slaves freedom by ordering him from a southern to a northern Post. Places under the ex- clusive jurisdiction of the U. S. are legislate dfor specially by Congress. It is perhap needless to remark that ist has passed no law prohibiting slavery within the garrison of the U. S., or by officers of the army.

I think therefore the deft. had a right to hold the Complainants as his slaves at Fort Winnebago, if they were slaves before they were brought to said Post, because he is not a citizen or resident of this Territorym and because he is an officer of the U. S. Army.

This opinion I entertained and considered it the law of this country while I was the additional Judge of the United States for the Michigan Territory (of which this country was then a part)---that is from the year 1823 ot the year 1832. In the year 1828 I expressed this opinion to the defendant and to Captn. Smith also of the army. And I have known several officers in the army who held slaves for years past whilst stationed at posts in this Territory; amd I have never heard that their right to do so was questioned, or have myself doubted this right.

To the said 11th. Interrogatory I further answer that I am now a Farmer; that I was the sole judge of the U. S. for the district of country now embraced within the limits of Wiskonsan, during the period above stated; that I have been a member of the legislature from this district when it was a portion of Michigan, the Delegate in Congress from this Territory and the Governor of the Territory for the last three years.
To the 12th. and 13th. and 14th Interrogatories -
That I can give no farther answer or information (that I am aware of) than such as is contained in my answer to the preceding interrogatories.
This depostion is written and signed by me with my own hand this twenty fifth day of November A.D. 1844.
